articles.headline: Iowa Democrats Ask: Without the First-in-the-Nation Caucuses, Who Are We, Really?
articles.snippet: President Biden’s push to start the Democratic presidential nominating process in South Carolina has inspired a rush of wistful memories and soul searching in the Hawkeye State.
articles.abstract: President Biden’s push to start the Democratic presidential nominating process in South Carolina has inspired a rush of wistful memories and soul searching in the Hawkeye State.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES, Iowa — Every four years since 1972, Iowa has stolen the national spotlight as presidential aspirants infiltrated its coffee houses, parades, living rooms, high school gyms, community centers and the pork-grilling pavilion at the state fair.

articles.headline: Ukraine’s Allies Agree on Russian Oil Price Cap
articles.snippet: The plan to impose a top price of $60 a barrel on Russian crude will most likely make a small dent in the Kremlin’s revenue, but the White House hopes it will help avert an oil shock.
articles.abstract: The plan to impose a top price of $60 a barrel on Russian crude will most likely make a small dent in the Kremlin’s revenue, but the White House hopes it will help avert an oil shock.
articles.lead_paragraph: An elaborate United States-led plan to limit what Russia can charge for its oil exports is set to cap the price of Russian crude at $60 a barrel, the Group of 7 nations agreed on Friday. The threshold, which was settled on after protracted negotiations among European Union diplomats, is likely to make a small dent in the Kremlin’s energy revenue and, the White House hopes, help avert a global oil shock.
articles.byline: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Jim Tankersley and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: United Auto Workers Appear to Rebuke Leaders in First Vote by Members
articles.snippet: Insurgent candidates showed strength, citing corruption scandals and calling for a tougher bargaining approach. The union president seems headed for a runoff.
articles.abstract: Insurgent candidates showed strength, citing corruption scandals and calling for a tougher bargaining approach. The union president seems headed for a runoff.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first United Auto Workers election open to all members appears to have produced a wave of opposition to the established leadership, signaling the prospect of sweeping changes for a union tarnished by a series of corruption scandals.

articles.headline: Twitter Keeps Missing Its Advertising Targets as Woes Mount
articles.snippet: Under Elon Musk, the company has cut its financial expectations as some advertisers request discounts and are offered incentives.
articles.abstract: Under Elon Musk, the company has cut its financial expectations as some advertisers request discounts and are offered incentives.
articles.lead_paragraph: The World Cup has historically been a boon for Twitter, bringing in record traffic and an influx of advertising dollars.
articles.byline: By Ryan Mac, Mike Isaac and Kate Conger

articles.headline: As Macron Loses His Sheen at Home, Harmonious U.S. Visit Is ‘Regenerative’
articles.snippet: President Emmanuel Macron, dealing with a difficult start to his second term, can return to France feeling buoyed by a warm reception and unity on Ukraine.
articles.abstract: President Emmanuel Macron, dealing with a difficult start to his second term, can return to France feeling buoyed by a warm reception and unity on Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Serenaded by a jazz band at the airport, cheered by crowds as he strolled through the French Quarter and even attempting a few dance steps, President Emmanuel Macron plunged into the most French of American cities on Friday, the last lap of his state visit to the United States.

articles.headline: He Returned a Dazed Soldier to the Russians. Ukraine Calls It Treason.
articles.snippet: No one knew what to do with a lost Russian pilot who suddenly appeared in the occupied city of Kherson. The case has revealed the blurred line between pragmatism in a war zone and collaboration with the enemy.
articles.abstract: No one knew what to do with a lost Russian pilot who suddenly appeared in the occupied city of Kherson. The case has revealed the blurred line between pragmatism in a war zone and collaboration with the enemy.
articles.lead_paragraph: KHERSON, Ukraine — On the night of March 15, Illia Karamalikov received an unexpected phone call.
articles.byline: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Finbarr O'Reilly

articles.headline: Defaults Loom as Poor Countries Face an Economic Storm
articles.snippet: Debt-relief efforts are stalling as developing economies are being hit by higher interest rates, a strong dollar and slowing global growth.
articles.abstract: Debt-relief efforts are stalling as developing economies are being hit by higher interest rates, a strong dollar and slowing global growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Developing nations are facing a catastrophic debt crisis in the coming months as rapid inflation, slowing growth, rising interest rates and a strengthening dollar coalesce into a perfect storm that could set off a wave of messy defaults and inflict economic pain on the world’s most vulnerable people.

articles.headline: In Georgia, a Heated Senate Race Stirs Mixed Emotions in Black Voters
articles.snippet: The contest might have been a showcase of Black political power in the Deep South. But many Black voters say Herschel Walker’s turbulent campaign has marred the moment.
articles.abstract: The contest might have been a showcase of Black political power in the Deep South. But many Black voters say Herschel Walker’s turbulent campaign has marred the moment.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our latest updates on the Georgia Senate runoff.
articles.byline: By Maya King, Clyde McGrady and Jazmine Ulloa

articles.headline: In Forests Full of Mines, Ukrainians Find Mushrooms and Resilience
articles.snippet: These misty and damp parts of the country have long beckoned to mushroom hunters with the promise of plenty, but now peril, too, lies beneath the earth’s surface.
articles.abstract: These misty and damp parts of the country have long beckoned to mushroom hunters with the promise of plenty, but now peril, too, lies beneath the earth’s surface.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZDVYZHIVKA, Ukraine — Deep in a pine forest to the north of Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, a beautiful mushroom warmed its brown cap in the gentle autumn sun — it was an all but irresistible scene for Ukrainian mushroom hunters.
articles.byline: By Maria Varenikova and Brendan Hoffman

articles.headline: The Chinese Dream, Denied
articles.snippet: The world’s harshest Covid restrictions exemplify how Xi Jinping’s authoritarian excesses have rewritten Beijing’s longstanding social contract with its people.
articles.abstract: The world’s harshest Covid restrictions exemplify how Xi Jinping’s authoritarian excesses have rewritten Beijing’s longstanding social contract with its people.
articles.lead_paragraph: The narrow alleyways of Haizhu district have long beckoned to China’s strivers, people like Xie Pan, a textile worker from a mountainous tea-growing area in central China.

articles.headline: Defamation Suit Against Fox Grows More Contentious
articles.snippet: Lachlan Murdoch is set to be deposed on Monday, the latest in a flurry of activity in the high-stakes case.
articles.abstract: Lachlan Murdoch is set to be deposed on Monday, the latest in a flurry of activity in the high-stakes case.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lachlan Murdoch, the chief executive of the Fox Corporation, is expected to be deposed on Monday as part of a $1.6 billion defamation lawsuit against Fox News for amplifying bogus claims that rigged machines from Dominion Voting Systems were responsible for Donald J. Trump’s defeat in 2020.

articles.headline: He’s the Bad Boy of Chess. But Did He Cheat?
articles.snippet: An American teenager, Hans Niemann, defeated Magnus Carlsen, the world’s best chess player. Then Mr. Carlsen accused his opponent of cheating. It’s either overdue justice or paranoia.
articles.abstract: An American teenager, Hans Niemann, defeated Magnus Carlsen, the world’s best chess player. Then Mr. Carlsen accused his opponent of cheating. It’s either overdue justice or paranoia.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By David Segal and Dylan Loeb McClain

articles.headline: Amid Churning Oil Market, OPEC and Russia Leave Production Unchanged
articles.snippet: The group, OPEC Plus, reaffirmed an output cut in October as “the right course of action” but outlined no other changes before an E.U. embargo of Russian oil begins on Monday.
articles.abstract: The group, OPEC Plus, reaffirmed an output cut in October as “the right course of action” but outlined no other changes before an E.U. embargo of Russian oil begins on Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: OPEC and its allies, including Russia, said on Sunday that they would leave their quotas for oil production unchanged. The group, known as OPEC Plus, appears to have decided during a teleconference that there was no reason to alter policy amid the many uncertainties in the oil market.

articles.headline: Iran Has Abolished Morality Police, an Official Suggests, After Months of Protests
articles.snippet: The move, which the government did not confirm, might be a concession to the protest movement that erupted after the death of a young woman in the custody of the morality police.
articles.abstract: The move, which the government did not confirm, might be a concession to the protest movement that erupted after the death of a young woman in the custody of the morality police.
articles.lead_paragraph: A senior Iranian official said this weekend that Iran had abolished the morality police, the state media reported, after months of protests set off by the death of a young woman who was detained by the force for supposedly violating the country’s strict Islamic dress laws.
articles.byline: By Vivian Yee and Farnaz Fassihi

articles.headline: A New Clash Between Faith and Gay Rights Arrives at a Changed Supreme Court
articles.snippet: A Colorado graphic designer says she has a First Amendment right to refuse to create websites for same-sex weddings despite a state anti-discrimination law.
articles.abstract: A Colorado graphic designer says she has a First Amendment right to refuse to create websites for same-sex weddings despite a state anti-discrimination law.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the Supreme Court hearings that pits free speech against gay rights.

articles.headline: Warnock and Walker, at Finish Line in Georgia, Stick to Their Strategies
articles.snippet: Senator Raphael Warnock preached from his Atlanta church and put on rallies, while Herschel Walker held a series of low-key events.
articles.abstract: Senator Raphael Warnock preached from his Atlanta church and put on rallies, while Herschel Walker held a series of low-key events.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The closely watched rematch between Senator Raphael Warnock and Herschel Walker has reached its final hours, capping an intense and turbulent campaign that has prompted debate over issues of race, class and power in a state with a pivotal role in American politics.
articles.byline: By Jazmine Ulloa, Maya King and Reid J. Epstein

articles.headline: Advice for Europeans: Bundle Up and Get Ready for Outages
articles.snippet: As temperatures drop amid an energy crisis, governments say power blackouts may be necessary to conserve electricity.
articles.abstract: As temperatures drop amid an energy crisis, governments say power blackouts may be necessary to conserve electricity.
articles.lead_paragraph: Life in some European cities may soon look like this: Staggered electricity outages to save energy. Temporary cuts in mobile phone and internet service. Schools closed for a lack of lighting and heat. Even traffic lights could briefly be powered down.

articles.headline: War and Sanctions Threaten to Thrust Russia’s Economy Back in Time
articles.snippet: While Russia’s economy has not collapsed, an exodus of Western companies is eroding hard-won progress, and experts say the worst may be yet to come.
articles.abstract: While Russia’s economy has not collapsed, an exodus of Western companies is eroding hard-won progress, and experts say the worst may be yet to come.
articles.lead_paragraph: KALUGA, Russia— Valery Volodin, a welder at a sprawling Volkswagen plant in western Russia, relaxed for most of the summer at his dacha, or weekend house, planting his garden and looking after his children. Mr. Volodin, 41, had little choice: The car factory closed down in March, joining more than 1,000 multinational companies that had curtailed operations in Russia because of its invasion of Ukraine.
articles.byline: By Valerie Hopkins and Anatoly Kurmanaev

articles.headline: The Crypto Industry Struggles for a Way Forward
articles.snippet: The implosion of the exchange FTX shows how an industry built in the wake of the 2008 financial crisis has drifted far from its original ideals.
articles.abstract: The implosion of the exchange FTX shows how an industry built in the wake of the 2008 financial crisis has drifted far from its original ideals.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Seems Ready to Back Web Designer Opposed to Same-Sex Marriage
articles.snippet: The justices are expected to settle a question left open in 2018: how to reconcile claims of religious liberty with laws barring discrimination based on sexual orientation.
articles.abstract: The justices are expected to settle a question left open in 2018: how to reconcile claims of religious liberty with laws barring discrimination based on sexual orientation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court’s conservative majority seemed prepared on Monday to rule that a graphic designer in Colorado has a free speech right under the First Amendment to refuse to create websites celebrating same-sex weddings because of her Christian faith, despite a state law that forbids discrimination based on sexual orientation.
